sentence.text: At one point Eva turned and gesticulated towards me , as if she were taking him to task for something he 'd done to me .
Another was hopeful of joining Ford -- he took me to task for this magazine 's criticisms of the new Escort .

He would certainly conclude that she was up to some adolescent mischief and take her to task again .
Your editors have been kind to me , seldom taking me to task -- ( or for that matter to lunch ) .
Last Friday , Meat Trade Suppliers was taken to task for ` seriously misleading " shareholders over a hostile offer .

In July 1200 Conrad of Mainz was taken to task for not having sent report to Rome about plans for the tribunal to decide on an emperor .
Landlords are taken to task over standards
Conrad was accordingly taken to task for not reporting to Rome and was ( wrongly ) reproved for taking part in the assembly .
LANDLORDS were taken to task today for running ` dirty , grubby and unfriendly " pubs .

The irony is that the Dutch , after nearly fifty years , still take the Germans to task , albeit jokingly , for having confiscated thousands of bicycles during the occupation .

It is not the first time he has taken his countrymen and women to task for what he considers their cultural failings .

Anyone who tried this line of argument would be taken to task by the pollsters , who have a commercial interest in resisting such reasoning .
Branches of Dillons , Books Etc and Bookland have been taken to task over the wording on their sale signposting and promotional material , including material provided by the National Book Sale .
